channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Haiti Braces for Catastrophe as Hurricane Matthew Makes Landfall
item.media:description: A Category 4 hurricane caused damage in the Dominican Republic overnight. Haiti, the poorest nation in the Western Hemisphere, also braced for heavy rains and mudslides.
item.description: The Category 4 storm brought winds of up to 145 miles an hour and rainfall that could exceed three feet in some areas.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Is Leftist Era Fading in Latin America? Ask Colombia and Brazil
item.media:description: Dilma Rousseff, a leftist, was impeached amid a divisive political climate in Brazil. Her predecessor and mentor, the once-powerful Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, faces a corruption inquiry.
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.description: The rejection of a peace deal in Colombia and leftist party losses in Brazil are the latest signs that conservatives are on the rise in the region.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Deep Scars and Complacency Defeated Colombia’s Peace Deal
item.media:description: Opponents of the deal between rebels and the Colombian government celebrated in Bogotá on Sunday as voters rejected it.
item.description: Months of polling had predicted a wide margin of victory for the agreement between the Colombian government and the FARC, the country’s largest rebel group.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE and NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Tension With Russia Rises as U.S. Halts Syria Negotiations
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, left, with Sergey V. Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister, in Geneva on Sept. 9, the day they announced the cease-fire.
item.description: The United States made good on a threat made last week, with the State Department calling it “not a decision that was taken lightly.”
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Tehran Journal: As Bugs Come for Its Mulberry Trees, a City Wraps Itself in Flypaper
item.media:description: Yellow flytape on park trees in Tehran, Iran. The city is in the midst of fighting a whitefly epidemic that has grown in intensity.
item.media:credit: Newsha Tavakolian for The New York Times
item.description: Solving an infestation of whiteflies in Tehran came down to this: Eradicate dust and pollution, or cut down all the mulberries. Officials try sticky paper instead.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte, Philippines’ Leader, Says Obama ‘Can Go to Hell’
item.media:description: Rodrigo Duterte, the Philippine president, in Taguig, east of Manila, on Tuesday.
item.description: Mr. Duterte, whose government is carrying out a deadly war on drugs, was angered by what he said was the United States’ refusal to sell weapons to the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Afghan Forces Push Taliban Out of Kunduz Center, Officials Say
item.media:description: Security forces in Kunduz, Afghanistan, on Tuesday. Afghan officials said that their commando forces had reclaimed the main city square from the Taliban.
item.description: After Afghan commandos arrive to battle an insurgent assault on the critical city, residents said that heavy fighting was spreading to other areas.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and NAJIM RAHIM

item.title: Outrage Over Fish Kill in Vietnam Simmers 6 Months Later
item.media:description: Protesters in Taipei, Taiwan, demonstrated in August against a chemical spill that killed tons of fish and that was attributed to the Formosa Ha Tinh Steel Corporation, a Taiwanese company.
item.description: Thousands of demonstrators swarmed a steel factory in Ha Tinh Province over the weekend, echoing the street protests in the country’s major cities in April.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Hammond Addresses ‘Brexit’ Turbulence With Hints of Policy Shift
item.media:description: Philip Hammond, the British chancellor of the Exchequer, at the International Convention Center in Birmingham, England, on Monday.
item.description: The chancellor of the Exchequer promised to take “whatever steps are necessary to protect this economy” as the country prepares to leave the European Union.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Pope Makes Surprise Visit to Earthquake-Hit Towns in Italy
item.media:description: Pope Francis with a firefighter in Amatrice, Italy, on Tuesday.
item.description: Francis vowed after the deadly tremor that he would travel to the region and pray with residents, but he had delayed the trip to avoid hindering rebuilding efforts.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Kim Kardashian Is Tied and Robbed of Millions in Jewels, French Police Say
item.media:description: The entrance of the luxury residence in Paris where masked men robbed the reality television star Kim Kardashian West at gunpoint early on Monday, stealing jewelry worth millions of dollars.
item.description: Officials in Paris promised an investigation into the attack on the TV star, who was robbed of $9 million in jewelry but was not physically injured.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER and ELIZABETH PATON

item.title: John Kerry Criticizes Russia, Saying It ‘Turned a Blind Eye’ on Syria
item.media:description: “The Syrian regime and Russia have rejected diplomacy, and seem to have chosen instead to continue their pursuit of a military victory over the broken bodies, bombed-out hospitals and traumatized children of a long-suffering land,” John Kerry said in Brussels on Tuesday.
item.description: The secretary of state said Moscow ignored President Bashar al-Assad’s use of chlorine gas and barrel bombs against his own people.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Tourists Take to the Road in Record Numbers for Golden Week
item.media:description: A record number of Chinese have hit the road this week for the National Day holiday, including these tourists crossing a bridge at West Lake in Hangzhou, Zhejiang Province.
item.description: People’s Daily, the Communist Party newspaper, said 589 million people were expected to travel this week — almost twice the population of the United States.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Julian Assange, WikiLeaks Founder, Promises Raft of Revelations
item.media:description: Julian Assange spoke via video link at a news conference in Berlin for the 10th anniversary of WikiLeaks on Tuesday. He vowed that the organization would continue to release classified documents from governments, institutions and others in positions of power.
item.description: On his organization’s 10th anniversary, he vowed to release “significant material” about a range of issues, including the U.S. election.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Australians Arrested in Malaysia After Stripping to Briefs at Grand Prix
item.media:description: Spectators with swimwear bearing a Malaysian flag at the Malaysian Grand Prix in Sepang on Sunday.
item.description: Nine men, including one said to be an aide to a cabinet minister, shed their clothes to reveal briefs that featured Malaysia’s flag.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES and MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: 3 Who Studied Unusual States of Matter Win Nobel Prize in Physics
item.media:description: Members of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences presenting this year’s Nobel Prize in Physics in Stockholm on Tuesday.
item.description: David J. Thouless, F. Duncan M. Haldane and J. Michael Kosterlitz were recognized for transforming the understanding of matter that assumes strange shapes.
item.dc:creator: DENNIS OVERBYE and SEWELL CHAN

item.title: The Interpreter: Colombia and ‘Brexit’ Show Why a Referendum Can Be Dangerous
item.media:description: Opponents of the Colombian peace agreement celebrating on Sunday in Bogotá, the capital, after the results of a national referendum were announced.
item.description: Though such votes are portrayed as popular governance in its purest form, studies have found that they often subvert democracy rather than serve it.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB and MAX FISHER

item.title: Letter From Europe: What Lies Behind French Conservatives’ Love of Putin?
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at a ceremony outside the Kremlin in June.
item.description: In the Soviet era, Moscow was a source of inspiration to the French left, and this has been amplified by a well-funded effort by Russia to woo the political elite.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: Nusra Front Says Drone Killed a Senior Leader in Syria
item.description: An American statement said Abu al Faraj al-Masri was the target of an American airstrike near Idlib, Syria. The militant group confirmed his death.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Jason Rezaian, Washington Post Reporter, Sues Iran Over Imprisonment
item.media:description: Jason Rezaian after being released from an Iranian prison in January.
item.description: The lawsuit accuses the Iranian government of holding Mr. Rezaian to extort concessions from the United States during negotiations on Tehran’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Protesters in Poland Rally Against Proposal for Total Abortion Ban
item.description: As many as 24,000 Poles, dressed in black, took to the streets in Warsaw to protest the proposed legislation. “Let them have their fun,” the foreign minister said.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: Trilobites: Roman Artifacts Found in Okinawa Castle
item.media:description: The excavation site where ancient Roman coins were discovered in the ruins of the Katsuren castle in Uruma, Okinawa.
item.media:credit: Uruma City Education Board, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: It’s unclear how ancient Roman coins ended up buried in the ruins of a 12th-century castle in Okinawa.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS BAKALAR

item.title: In Greek Warrior’s Grave, Rings of Power (and a Mirror and Combs)
item.media:description: An ivory comb recovered from the grave of an ancient Greek warrior.
item.description: Archaeologists believe that elegant gold rings and engraved gemstones were not looted from Crete, but were signs of the growth of Minoan culture from the island.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS WADE

item.title: Turkey Detains Brother of Fethullah Gulen, Cleric Accused of Plotting Coup
item.media:description: Turkey has demanded that the United States extradite Fethullah Gulen, a Muslim preacher who lives in exile in Pennsylvania.
item.description: Kutbettin Gulen was said to have been arrested in the west of the country in connection with membership in an “armed terror organization.”
item.dc:creator: SAFAK TIMUR
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Vladimir Putin Exits Nuclear Security Pact, Citing ‘Hostile Actions’ by U.S.
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the Kremlin in Moscow last month. He signed a decree on Monday pulling Russia out of a plutonium disposal treaty.
item.description: Citing a “radically changed environment” of hostility and threats, Mr. Putin withdrew from a 2000 agreement on the disposal of plutonium.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Jakarta Journal: What’s Clogging Jakarta’s Waterways? You Name It
item.media:description: An excavator getting trash out of a river in Jakarta, Indonesia, in August. The city is dredging its 17 rivers and canals — the first time it has done so since the 1970s.
item.media:credit: Kemal Jufri for The New York Times
item.description: Indonesia’s capital is working to dredge its network of rivers and canals, long blocked with garbage and a central contributor to chronic flooding.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Montreal’s Pit Bull Ban IsSuspended Until Wednesday
item.media:description: The final vote by the Montreal City Council was 37 to 23 in favor of the ban on pit bulls.
item.description: Critics of the new rules say the dogs are being unfairly singled out, and a lawsuit has been filed against the regulations.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Yoshinori Ohsumi of Japan Wins Nobel Prize for Study of ‘Self-Eating’ Cells
item.description: A cell biologist, Dr. Ohsumi was recognized for his work on autophagy, the process by which cells recycle their content.
item.dc:creator: GINA KOLATA and SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Sinosphere: The Cultural Revolution in Tibet: A Photographic Record
item.media:description: Tsering Woeser’s father, an officer in the People’s Liberation Army in Lhasa when the Cultural Revolution broke out in 1966, photographed many public attacks on Tibet’s old ruling class and religious leaders. Here, a Buddhist nun wears a sign labeling her as a counterrevolutionary.
item.description: The writer Tsering Woeser interviewed people who appeared in photographs her father, a People’s Liberation Army officer, took during the upheaval.
item.dc:creator: LUO SILING

item.title: Emboldened Taliban Overrun Parts of Kunduz and Taunt Afghan Forces
item.description: American officials said resources were being diverted to Kunduz, while the Taliban made gains in a separate assault in Helmand Province in the south.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: What in the World: Need to Land a Plane? In Australia, They Break Out the Toilet Paper
item.description: For the Royal Flying Doctor Service to arrive and land on a remote runway at night, about 30 cans with flaming rolls sometimes have to be lined up.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Royal Flying Doctor Service of Australia

item.title: What in the World: Lousy Libidos: Why Do Pandas Have So Little Sex?
item.media:credit: Illustration by Cari Vander Yacht; photo by Enmyo/Shutterstock
item.description: Pandas have a slim window each year for mating, but even then, they often don’t know what to do, so scientists have taken to offering them guidance.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Sociology, According to Putin
item.media:description: Lev D. Gudkov, director of the Levada Center, Russia’s only reputable independent polling organization, in 2013.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: The Kremlin fears sociologists even more than it needs them.
item.dc:creator: MASHA GESSEN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Problem With the Islamic Apocalypse
item.media:description: An Islamic State mural in Shirqat, Iraq, last month.
item.description: Too many Muslims, not just radicals, believe that the end times are near. They should instead focus on this lifetime.
item.dc:creator: MUSTAFA AKYOL
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Chappatte on Colombia’s Failed Peace Deal
item.description: A narrow defeat plunges a nation back into uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK CHAPPATTE

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
